story:
*For International Shipping of Perks: Please contact us For arrangements if you would like the shipped Perks and live overseas!*

UPDATE 9/22/2016: A fan has reached out to help us find a better shipping price and now we will only need $200 for the printing +shipping of the flyers! This moves our ultimate goal to $450 as opposed to $800-- basically half the price!!! 

Who are we?

We are Perfume fans on a mission.

Perfume is a Japanese pop group, originally from Hiroshima, Japan. The 3 girls have dazzled Japan and the world, and are returning to America as an extension of their most recent album tour, Cosmic Explorer. 

As fans, traditionally we have organized to sing an "encore" song at the end of the concert, as a means of goodwill and support to the girls. It's become a semi-tradition at concerts internationally, and for Perfume's first visit to Chicago, we'd like to make it a memorable one.

With the international community and the nature of music in a foreign language, these flyers allow fans to have a 'cheat sheet' to sing along in unity so we can leave a lasting impression of love for every city the girls visit. These flyers also serve as memorabilia for fans who visit each city and concert. 

By contributing, you would allow yourself and other fans to join hands and sing together for the girls who have worked so hard to come and sing for us.

What We Need & What You Get

  • $200 - Printing. The price of printing 2,000 copies of flyers for the event. This is as cheap as we could find this short of notice. These flyers are meant to be distributed and shared to a concert of 3,000 people. 
  • $150 - Artist fees. We need to pay an artist for their time and rushing this art for our flyers so that we have something beautiful and memorable to look at.
  • $150 - Design. To design the flyers and edit to ensure the lyrics are correct, we will need to pay someone to edit the images and lyrics to appear both clearly and in an easy to read format, without distracting from the art.
The music selected for this event was "Perfume" by Perfume, due to it's ease of singing and chanting in both English and Japanese. We feel short notice it will be easy for fans to gather and sing loud together, even in Japanese.

Risks & Challenges

We realize this is very short notice. This is a huge set back to designing and printing these flyers. Without support and the banding together of fans, we cannot make this a reality. 

If we do not meet our goal, we will attempt to print as many lyric sheets as possible and cover whatever we can as we can. Since this is a fan practice, by fans and for fans, we urge you to take part in Perfume history and help us welcome them warmly to Chicago. Everyone is running short on time, but we are full of love, so the only thing between us now is the finances to produce the items.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, consider sharing us within your Perfume fan communities. The more word out about this, the quicker we can reach our goal and get the flyers made and distributed at the event.

Please share and help us make Chicago a city of memories for the girls of PERFUME!


The Song

"Perfume"

JAPANESE:

Ｓ極とＮ極の様にね　今　引き合うの
Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Perfume
Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Perfume

トップノート照れ臭いけど
ミドルノートいつもありがと
ラストノート波止まらず
歌える　今日を抱きしめる

香り効能ほら心に聞いて感じてみてね
バリア解いたらねぇ？！アコードはどんな香りをしてる？

トップノート出会えた奇跡
ミドルノート忘れないでね
ラストノート消えない思い
私のここが居場所なの

強い運命さあ複雑に甘く組み合わせるの
温度上がると君新しい香り始まり知ってる？

他人同士だからねいろんな世界磁力を待ったの

Ｓ極とＮ極の様にね　今　引き合うの
Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Perfume
Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Pa·Perfume

トップノートたれく差異けど
ミドルノートいつもありがと
ラストノート波止まらず
歌える　今日を抱きしめる

強い運命さあ複雑に甘く組み合わせるの温度上がると君新しい香り始まり知ってる？
他人同士だからねいろんな世界磁力を待ったの

story:
Hello friends and fans! 


We're Pete and Trish, The Grant Street Grifters. Almost eight years ago, we played what we thought was a one-off gig; a store opening at a mall. We only had about 50 minutes of material, and it was not what you would call polished. After we played each song about 15 times during the event, however, we started to sound like we knew what we were doing and we decided to keep going at it. 

Through the years, we have had the opportunity to play some of our favorite venues and share the stage with some amazing musicians. This couldn't have happened without you! You have clicked on all of those Facebook events, you have shown up to eat and drink and dance in the venues we've played, you've invited us to play your barbecues, birthday parties, even weddings. We are eternally grateful for all of your support over the years. 

Now, we have one more small thing to ask of you. 

As you've seen, we recently recorded an EP -- five of our original songs. We are hoping that this will help us share our music with an even wider audience. To make this a reality, we are asking you for your help. In this campaign, we are offering you the chance to pre-order the album, merchandise, and other perks. Your donation to IndieGoGo will help us cover the cost of mastering, printing and packaging, and will get this album out to market much sooner than it otherwise would. 

This band is at a turning point. We just finished six successful shows throughout the mid-west and Ontario, Canada. Creatively, we we're on top of our game, and this album will really help us spread the word. Our goal is your goal: bigger and better Grant Street Grifters! 

So please help out in any way you can, either through a donation or just sharing the link to this campaign with your friends and associates on social media. 


* * *

About Grant Street Grifters
Formed in 2008, the acoustic duo specializes in Folk, Old-Time, and Blues and is based in southwest Pennsylvania's Steel City. Since their inception, Peter Flynn (guitar/vocals) and Trish Imbrogno (double bass/vocals) have been a fixture in the Pittsburgh music scene, as well as sharing their talents up and down the I-79 corridor. The combination of their polar opposite playing styles lends a unique sound to traditional American Folk music. 

The duo met as students at Duquesne University. Trish was on her way to a Bachelor's Degree in double bass performance and Pete was on his way to, well ... nothing in particular. Trish headed west, Pete stayed in Pittsburgh, and they wouldn’t see each other very much over the next ten years. But, thanks to the magic of online social networking, they were able to reconnect, and eventually musical duo was born. 

Grant Street Grifters began their career as "The Grifters" at L.L. Bean, after Trish received a call from their headquarters in Freeport, Maine. They were about to finish construction of their newest store at Ross Park Mall and were looking to have live acoustic music for the grand opening. 

As Trish recalls, she may have been a little loose with the facts when she accepted the gig: 
“The call was completely unexpected. When the woman on the phone explained who she was and what she wanted, I was like ‘Sure, I’m in a band that fits what you’re looking for.’ Then I called Pete and told him we need to put a band together and learn a bunch of songs ASAP! We started practicing and a few weeks later I received an email asking for the name of our band, which of course we hadn’t thought of yet. Pete chose ‘The Grifters’, since we had kind of conned our way into the gig.” 

Growing up in a musical family, Pete had been playing the guitar since age eight and started to show an interest in traditional American music in his early high school years. During those years, when most of his musician friends were worshiping Hendrix and Jimmy Page, Pete had a different set of guitar heroes – the acoustic guitar wizards who were discovered and rediscovered in the great folk music boom of the early sixties. He dusted off his dad’s old records and immersed himself in the music of Dave Van Ronk, Mississippi John Hurt, Rev. Gary Davis and Doc Watson. 

Trish grew up listening to hard rock and heavy metal, even playing in an early 90s "hair band." She saw the light in her teens and became interested in the sounds of the Grateful Dead, Phish, The Allman Brothers and other more roots-oriented bands, all the while studying Beethoven, Bach and Mozart. She didn't try her hand at playing the music to which she listened until 2007 when she co-founded The Polished Pearls, a duo with singer/songwriter and music therapist Andrea Scheve that eventually grew into a acoustic quintet. 

One of the players to round out the band was Pete on lead guitar. The Pearls played a series of shows over the next year with Trish gaining the confidence to actually play something off the page and Pete regaining his chops.

But just when it all came together, it all fell apart. Andrea was forced to relocate to California and the band was no more. Enter a phone call from Maine, and the rest is what lies before you. 

What does it sound like when a metal head turned Deadhead classical bassist and acoustic roots guitarist get together? You'll have to hear for yourself...


All photos ©Todd Brunozzi Photography

story:
More Music:  Stretch goal of $3500 = 4 More CDs added to Perks... So, 6 in total on the way :-)

Immense thanks to everyone who has helped us reach the first goal.  We are now able to build a fantastic studio computer to replace the 10 year old Windows XP box.  Yeah!

Our new target helps purchase a few more microphones, suited to recording live percussive instruments (bohdran, djembe, cajon), and gives the studio the option of tracking more than one acoustic guitar/mandolin/violin at the same time in the studio or on stage.  You rock!!

And if we reach this goal, then you can get extra perks! 
Everyone that has pledged $25 or more is already getting two new CDs of music being created this summer... the mix of original, cover, and parody/Filk songs.  30 songs minimum!

In fact, I've already started writing...
Here's a scratch track of the first perk song request... "Watching It On Netflix", recorded at 4:30am Thursday morning.  Can't wait to redo it with the new system!

And if we reach $3500, there will be 4 more CDs worth of music added to the contribution level of $25 or more:


Kari Maaren's current CD "Everybody Hates Elves" via download!  Keep or share, it's your code to use as you see fit. Rumour has it that Kari has another project in the planning stages... so it's a good idea to get to know her now :-)

The Faithful Sidekicks brand new CD "*.* and Other Star Things" via download!
Go check it out at the link (only if you like geeky things with the word "Star" in them.  Or if you like coffee.  Or Dr. Who. or....)

Plus 2 more full length projects: "Background Music for Any Planet Vol 1 & 2". 

I don't know if it's possible to conjure the Geek using just instrumentals, but I'm going to try.  I want to create music that is good to support small gatherings... board games, crafting, RPG, etc.  One project will be softer, ambient stuff... the second will have more pace and energy.
Due Date: mid 2017 (sorry about the wait.. but we have so much cool stuff going on in the first year, that I don't want to under deliver on this one)

But there's still a challenge to solve: what songs should we do?

The top tier perks levels for the campaign are getting full (thank you!), and the focus now shifts to finding people that have ideas for cover songs, parodies, and originals.  We've had a few ideas already, and they are FANTASTIC.  Let's get some more! 

Who do we know that would love a custom song created?  Who has a dream of hearing their song idea come to life?  The links below show that we can create good sounding stuff together... let's find the people that share this passion of ours!



Original Campaign notes below...

Alter Ego Music has helped over 60 music artists (on-line and in person) over the past decade.  In the past year alone, 25 "Geek" and "Filk" artists have had work go through the studio, and just as many more used some of the gear for conventions and stage performances!

The heart of the recording studio is the computer... and although it is still going strong (sometimes), the original Windows XP machine is finally going off line.  And I would like your help to build a massively good replacement.


In exchange for your help, there are 3 tiers of perks lined up for you to consider:

  1. Entry Level: You get copies of some or all of the music created this year.  Thank you very much... sharing our music is the reason we make it in the first place!

  2. Mid Level: You get all the music created, plus you get to tell us what songs you want to hear... over 30 in total, please.  I want to deliver a mix of original songs, covers, parodies, and Filk songs.  Hopefully more if you ask for it!

  3. Top Level: You get time to work on your songs in the studio... on-line or in person.  Plus you get copies of all songs created as part of this campaign.

For anyone interested in the technical details for the new computer, I have put those at the end of the campaign page.  But before we get to the plans for The New Hotness, here is a quick peek at Old & Busted:

Ah... the dreams I had back in 2006...probably still good for StarCraft 1.


Studio Samples & Contributing Artists:

To celebrate the 10 year milestone (and launch the next era in fine style), over a dozen artists are joining me in the studio this year, to provide some custom music in exchange for your help with this campaign. 

Here are some samples that were recorded in the studio over the past 5 years.  Please click through the song titles to access some great music...

  1. Bill Craig, doing his cover of Stan Rogers "Witch of the Westmoreland"
  2. Kari Maaren, with her original song "Everybody Hates Elves"
  3. Devin Melanson & Jessica Nelson feat Adam Hill on vocals  "Yes Or No"
  4. Devin Melanson feat Leslie Hudson on vocal "Threat Detected" podcast
  5. Devin Melanson & Leslie Hudson as Copy Red Leader  "Tatooine Blues"


    Join the Dark Side... we have headphones (clockwise from top left: Heather, Chris, Tracie, & Samantha)


    Other Artists working with us on this project:


    • Peter Watkinson lives in Amsterdam, and he sends us some lovely metal via his music project Abomnium
    • We have Rock and Pop on tap from our great friend John at Das Binky
    • Toronto's original and longest lasting geek duo of awesome consists of Alex & Sean from Nerds with Guitars.  Check out their song "Sympathy for the Daleks"
    • The stellar duo Debs & Errol are also helping.  Check out their stuff here
    • Eric and Jen bring us brand new geek music as The Faithful Sidekicks
    • Peter at Rock Paper Cynic has a new album coming out... and for now, you can check out his other stuff over here

    The last (musical) word? Don't forget the Filk at FKO this year!

    I am delighted to be invited back to Filk Ontario this year to help with sound at the live stage.  Last year was a blast... and this year, I'm bringing more toys to help record the performances.  That's right: Alter Ego Music is joining forces with USB Studios to capture the show, and we hope to reveal plans to mix and master the songs performed at FKO 26, April 8th - 10th.

    In the meantime, we will close out the music samples with some more folks that proudly call themselves "Filkers":

    • Here are Morva and Alan with their song "Mockingjay"
    • Phil Mills is also a Filker... check out his song "The Once Upon A Time", and then check out more of his catalog here.

    Both of these songs appeared on a recent charity CD called "Filkus Borealis" that I was very glad to work on.  See?  Music can be used for good!

    And now, more happy recording peoples... then some tech details & evil plans.

    Left to right, from top: Debs & Leslie in the foreground, doing background vocals for Kari, who sits in the background after recording her vocals foremost.

    Far right: Peter from Abomnium tries to keep up with the house drummer

    And now, some details.

    Footnotes for the 5 pieces of sample music

    1. Bill Craig performed this cover of "The Witch of the Westmoreland" in a single take, using two microphones and the direct out from his acoustic guitar.  He rocked it!  Bill toured with The Irish Rovers back in the day.  *respect*
    2. Kari Maaren, also records voice and ukulele together, often in one take as well. I have the hardest time staying quiet when recording with Kari, as her first take is always great, but I have to stifle myself from laughing every time I hear one of her new songs.
    3. Devin Melanson & Jessica Nelson feat Adam Hill on vocals  "Yes Or No"  Jess wrote this lyric for FAWM in 2013, and I wrote the music and vocal melody.  Then I reached out to Adam, and he recorded his vocal in his home studio, which was sent to me for processing and mixing here.
    4. Devin Melanson feat Leslie Hudson on vocal "Threat Detected" podcast.  Our good friend Garrett Crowe runs many fine geek things as your barefoottourguide at threat-detected.com  Go check out his games and podcasts!
    5. Devin Melanson & Leslie Hudson as Copy Red Leader  "Tatooine Blues".  Working with Leslie on the Copy Red Leader project created many opportunities to refine the work process for both studio and live recording.  Make sure you (try to) keep up to her other prolific projects over here!

    Project specific detail #1: High level timeline:

    • March 2016 (early) - Complete a successful Indiegogo campaign!
    • March 2016 (late) - Final selection of computer hardware
    • April 2016(early) - Build computer system & integrate the following hardware and software (in this order): Cubase DAW (software), UAD 1 & 2 cards (hardware & software... may require code to integrate these two generations), PreSonus 1818VSL (hardware & software), Toontrack (software), Other purchased VST plugs (software), Remote Control development (Android tablet/iPad control via PreSonus Virtual Software), integrate MOTU 828 MKii with PreSonus 1818 VSL (external clock, SPIDF & ADAT optical)
    • April 2016 (late): publish technical details of how the system works (including any software/hardware patches created)
    • May thru November 2016: write, record, mix & master the 30+ songs to fulfill perks (plus any artist projects that are scheduled)
    • December 2016 (early): make all songs available


    Project specific detail #2: The computer build.  First, some basic components that are required to build the new computer:

    • Power Supply: Corsair RM650M
    • CPU: Intel I7 4790K (4th Gen)
    • OS: Win7 Pro X64

    Now, some things that *should* work together (I'm pretty sure they will work together) in special ways, due to the requirements of this build:

    • Case: Rosewill RSV-Z2600 (rack mounted, for recording live stage events and other portable recording needs)
    • Mainboard: Asus H97M-Plus (supports the 2 additional UAD processor expansion boards that need to be integrated via PCI)
    • RAM: Crucial Ballistix Tactical LP 16GB (needs to fit in the case!)
    • CPU Fan: Noctua NH-L9x65 (needs to be quiet in the studio)
    • System Hard Drive: Samsung EVO 850 M2 250GB (fast SSD for all the operating systems, effects plugins, and soft synths)
    • Audio File Data Drives: A pair of WD Black 3TB (programmed to immediately store all audio as it is recorded, with a mirrored copy on each drive for failsafe redundancy)
    • Case Fans: Enermax UCTB8 (three of these, and they also must be quiet)
    • Internal USB ports: There are several licensing keys & dongles that enable software to run.  These will be mounted inside the case, to prevent damage when the computer is moved.
    • Some sort of portable display when booting the system.  Once everything is started, I will be able to control the studio via iPad (similar to the stage shows I've helped with).  This is really nice in live music situations.

    Alex and Sean from Nerds with Guitars, helping fulfill another Geek Artist's perks  (namely Peter from Rock Paper Cynic!)

    Whew... that's the details of when, and what, things will happen.  Thank you for reading through until the end... your patience is appreciated!


    I am really looking forward to getting the system up and running, and recording some new music.  And I hope that you can help out, and tell me what music you want to hear.  It would be great to work with you!

    Thanks again,

    Devin

     1818VSL (hardware & software), Toontrack (software), Other purchased
     VST plugs (software), Remote Control development (Android tablet/iPad
     control via PreSonus Virtual Software), integrate MOTU 828 MKii with
     PreSonus 1818 VSL (external clock, SPIDF & ADAT optical)
April 2016 (late): publish
     technical details of how the system works (including any software/hardware
     patches created)
May thru November 2016:
     write, record, mix & master the 30+ songs to fulfill perks (plus any
     artist projects that are scheduled)
December 2016 (early): make
     all songs available


Project specific detail #2: The computer build.  First, some basic components that are required to build the new computer:

Power Supply: Corsair RM650M
CPU: Intel I7 4790K (4th
     Gen)
OS: Win7 Pro X64

Now, some
things that *should* work together (I'm pretty sure they will work together) in
special ways, due to the requirements of this build:

Case: Rosewill RSV-Z2600
     (rack mounted, for recording live stage events and other portable
     recording needs)
Mainboard: Asus H97M-Plus (supports
     the 2 additional UAD processor expansion boards that need to be
     integrated via PCI)
RAM: Crucial Ballistix
     Tactical LP 16GB (needs to fit in the case!)
CPU Fan: Noctua NH-L9x65
     (needs to be quiet in the studio)
System Hard Drive: Samsung
     EVO 850 M2 250GB (fast SSD for all the operating systems, effects plugins,
     and soft synths)
Audio File Data Drives: A
     pair of WD Black 3TB (programmed to immediately store all audio as it is
     recorded, with a mirrored copy on each drive for failsafe redundancy)
Case Fans: Enermax UCTB8
     (three of these, and they also must be quiet)
Internal USB ports: There
     are several licensing keys & dongles that enable software to
     run.  These will be mounted inside the case, to prevent damage when
     the computer is moved.
Some sort of portable
     display when booting the system.  Once everything is started, I will
     be able to control the studio via iPad (similar to the stage shows I've
     helped with).  This is really nice in live music situations.
